solution:
\begin{soln}
  As $f$ is continuous, by EVT, there exists $c\in [0,1]$
  such that $f(x)\le f(c)$ for all $x\in [0,1]$.
  Therefore,
  \[
    \int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x
    \le \int_{0}^{1} f(c)^{n} \mathrm{d}x
    = f(c)^{n}
  \]
  which implies
  \[
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
    \le f(c)
  .\]
  Now by
  continuity of $f$ at $x=c$, we get that for all
  $\eps>0$ there exists $\delta > 0$ such that
  for all $x\in [0,1]$,
  \[
    |x-c| < \delta \implies |f(x)-f(c)| < \eps,
  \]
  that is, $f(x)\in (f(c)-\eps, f(c)+\eps)$ for all
  $x\in (c-\delta, c+\delta)\cap [0,1]$. Fix $\eps>0$.
  Let $\mathcal{I}=(c-\delta, c+\delta)\cap[0,1]$
  and let $\ell $ be the length of the interval
  $\mathcal{I}$.
  Therefore,
  \[
    \int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x
    \ge \int_{\mathcal{I}} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x
    \ge \int_{\mathcal{I}} (f(c)-\eps)^n \mathrm{d}x
    = (f(c)-\eps)^n \cdot \ell
  \]
  which implies
  \[
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
    \ge (f(c)-\eps)\cdot \ell^{{1}/{n}}
  .\]
  Clearly $\left\{ \ell^{{1}/{n}} \right\}_{n \ge 1}$ is
  bounded below. Therefore,
  \[
    \left\{ 
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
    \right\}_{n \ge 1}
  \]
  is bounded both above and below.
  This implies that both
  \[
    \liminf_{n \to \oo}
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
    \quad\text{and}\quad
    \limsup_{n \to \oo}
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
  \]
  exist.

  Clearly $\lim_{n \to \oo} (f(c)-\eps)\cdot \ell^{{1}/{n}}
  =f(c)-\eps$.
  Considering limit superior and limit inferior in the
  following inequality:
  \[
    (f(c)-\eps)^{{1}/{n}}\le
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
    \le f(c)
  \]
  we get
  \[
    f(c)-\eps\le\liminf_{n \to \oo}
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
    \le f(c)
  \]
  and
  \[
    f(c)-\eps\le\limsup_{n \to \oo}
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
    \le f(c)
  \]
  for any arbitrary $\eps>0$.
  Considering small $\eps$, we get
  \[
    \liminf_{n \to \oo}
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
    = \limsup_{n \to \oo}
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
    = f(c)
  \]
  which implies
  \[
    \limsup_{n \to \oo}
    \left(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)^n \mathrm{d}x\right)^{{1}/{n}}
    =f(c).\qedhere
  \]
\end{soln}

\begin{remark*}{Motivation}{}
  From where does one motivate the fact that the limit
  should be the maximum value of the function? Well, if
  this were a finite discrete sum instead of an integral,
  that is,
  \[
    \left(
    \frac{a_1^n + a_2^n + \dots + a_{d}^n}{n}
    \right)^{{1}/{n}},
  \]
  then the limit simply would've been $\max_{i}a_i$.
  (Left as an exercise to the reader.) Since an integral
  is basically a continuous sum instead of a discrete one,
  it suggests that the limit might be the
  maximum/supremum
  value that $f$ attains on it's entire domain.
\end{remark*}
